docs.title: MkDocs
docs.text: For full documentation visit mkdocs.org.

docs.title: Commands-mkdocs
docs.text:
• mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project.
  • mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server.
  • mkdocs build - Build the documentation site.
  • mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit.

docs.title: Command-venv-activate
docs.text: • venv/Scripts/activate - Activate virtual environment in terminal.

docs.title: Codeblocks
docs.text: Some code goes here.

docs.title: Plain codeblock
docs.text:
A plain codeblock:

Some code here
def myfunction()
// some comment

docs.title: Code for a specific language
docs.text:
Some more code with the py at the start:

import tensorflow as tf
def whatever()

docs.title: With a title
With line numbers
docs.text:
def bubble_sort(items):
for i in range(len(items)):
for j in range(len(items) - 1 - i):
if items[j] > items[j + 1]:
items[j], items[j + 1] = items[j + 1], items[j]

docs.title: Highlighting lines
docs.text:
def bubble_sort(items):
for i in range(len(items)):
for j in range(len(items) - 1 - i):
if items[j] > items[j + 1]:
items[j], items[j + 1] = items[j + 1], items[j]

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: Minecraft Forge is a modding framework, designed to allow different mods to load and work together to be compatible.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
• What is MDK? The Mod Development Kit or MDK is a downloadable archive that contains the basic skeleton for starting a new mod. It contains the following files and folders:

The Mod Development Kit

  • The Mod Development Kit
  • gradle/wrapper/ - The folder containing the Gradle wrapper, Forge uses Version 7.4.2
  • src - The sources folder
    • main - The main source set
    • java - The java sources for the main source set
      • ...
    • resources - The resources for the main source set
      • META-INF - The folder for metadata information files1
      • mods.toml - The mods.toml file, where mods are declared
      • pack.mcmeta - File used by Minecraft to identify data and resource packs
  • .gitattributes - Used by Git for specifying attributes for files2
  • .gitignore - Used by Git for specifying intentionally untracked/ignored files3
  • build.gradle - The Gradle buildscript, which defines the project and tasks4
  • changelog.txt - The Forge version changelog
  • CREDITS.txt - Forge's credits/thank you file
  • gradle.properties - The Gradle properties file, for defining additional variables and options5
  • gradlew - The *nix shell file for executing the Gradle wrapper
  • gradlew.bat - The Windows batch file for executing the Gradle wrapper
  • LICENSE.txt - File containing the licensing information for Forge and libraries
  • README.txt - Readme file with the basic setup instructions

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Some Basic Java Knowledge
  • IDE installed of your choice - ["IntelliJ IDEA/Eclipse/Visual Studio Code"]

docs.title: Setup Forge MDK
docs.text:
1. Download the MDK from the official Minecraft Forge download site and extract the MDK into an empty folder.
  2. Open your IDE of choice, and import the project as a Gradle project.
  3. For Eclipse: File > Import > Gradle > Existing Gradle Project, select the folder for the Project root directory, click Finish
  4. For IntelliJ IDEA: File > Open, select and open the folder, select the build.gradle file, click OK, click Open as Project
  5. For Visual Studio Code: Run ./gradlew buildNeeded and then ./gradlew eclipse, then File > Open Folder... and select the folder
  6. Wait for the setup process to complete and the Minecraft sources are decompiled.
  7. For Visual Studio Code: This step can be skipped as it was already done in the previous step
  8. Generate the run configurations for your IDE using the appropriate Gradle task. These tasks can be run in the terminal using ./gradlew gen***Runs. For Eclipse: the task is genEclipseRuns; to run in the IDE directly, open the Gradle Tasks tab on the bottom panel, wait until the tasks have loaded then expand the folder, expand the fgruns folder, then double-click _genEclipseRuns. For IntelliJ IDEA: the task is genIntellijRuns; to run in the IDE directly, open the Gradle on the right, expand the project folder, double-click Tasks > fg_runs > genIntellijRuns. For Visual Studio Code: the task is genVSCodeRuns; the Extension Pack for Java and Gradle for Java plugin should both be installed for smoother integration.

docs.title: Customizing the MDK
docs.text:
The MDK provides default values for the buildscript and mods.toml file. These values should be replaced with your own mod's information.

All edits should be done below the id 'net.minecraftforge.gradle' line. The lines above it are required for the Forge MDK to work correctly, and should not be modified without proper knowledge.

All references to examplemod in the buildscript should be replaced with your modid. Use your IDE's find-and-replace function to quickly replace these values. Pick a unique and memorable modid. The modid must be between 2 and 64 characters, and must consist of lowercase letters, numbers, underscores (_) and hyphens (-). The recommendation is to avoid using acronyms and abbreviations. Change the archivesBaseName variable to your modid. This is used as the base name for the JAR file when you build your mod, and as the artifactId of your mod's maven coordinates. Change the group to your unique root java package. This is used as the groupId of your mod's maven coordinates. In the jar task, change the values of the Specification-Vendor and Implementation-Vendor keys to your username/brand name or other form of identification. Optional suggestion: Change the version variable to have a 0 as the major version (ex. '0.1'). This is to follow semantic versioning guidelines for versions in active development.

docs.title: Building and Testing
docs.text:
You can test your mod in the development environment using either your IDE's run configurations and built-in debugging utilities, or by running the run* task as defined by the buildscript's run configurations.

There are four default run configurations with the MDK:

  • runClient, for starting the client.
  • runServer, for starting the dedicated server. You will need to accept the EULA through the eula.txt after running the server for the first time.
  • runData, for starting the client in data generation mode.
  • runGameTestServer, for starting a build server to run game tests.

You can build your mod's final JAR using the build task. The resulting JAR will be located in the build/libs folder under your project directory.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: Now you are setup with the mod initial setup and can start adding all the features you want.

docs.title: Markdown Cheat Sheet
docs.text:
Thanks for visiting The Markdown Guide!

This Markdown cheat sheet provides a quick overview of all the Markdown syntax elements. It can’t cover every edge case, so if you need more information about any of these elements, refer to the reference guides for basic syntax and extended syntax.

docs.title: Basic Syntax
docs.text: These are the elements outlined in John Gruber’s original design document. All Markdown applications support these elements.

docs.title: Bold
docs.text: bold text

docs.title: Italic
docs.text: italicized text

docs.title: Blockquote
docs.text: blockquote

docs.title: Ordered List
docs.text:
1. First item
  2. Second item
  3. Third item

docs.title: Unordered List
docs.text:
• First item
  • Second item
  • Third item

docs.title: Code
docs.text: code

docs.title: Link
docs.text: Markdown Guide

docs.title: Extended Syntax
docs.text: These elements extend the basic syntax by adding additional features. Not all Markdown applications support these elements.

docs.title: Table
docs.text: Syntax Description Header Title Paragraph Text

docs.title: Fenced Code Block
docs.text:
{
"firstName": "John",
"lastName": "Smith",
"age": 25
}

docs.title: Footnote
docs.text: Here's a sentence with a footnote. 1

docs.title: Definition List
docs.text: term : definition

docs.title: Strikethrough
docs.text: ~~The world is flat.~~

docs.title: Task List
docs.text:
• [x] Write the press release
  • [ ] Update the website
  • [ ] Contact the media

docs.title: Emoji
docs.text:
That is so funny!

(See also Copying and Pasting Emoji)

docs.title: Highlight
docs.text: I need to highlight these very important words.

docs.title: Superscript
docs.text:
X^2^

  1. This is the footnote. ↩
